text: Evaluation of School-Based Smoking-Cessation Interventions for Self-Described Adolescent Smokers
WHAT'S KNOWN ON THIS SUBJECT: Classroom-based, group smoking-cessation programs have been shown to enhance attempts to quit smoking among mostly white youths.
Whether such interventions would be effective if delivered in alternative formats to a more racially diverse population of smokers is not known.
WHAT THIS STUDY ADDS: The NOT program, reformatted to a twice-weekly lunchtime intervention, was modestly effective in enhancing quit rates among a racially diverse group of adolescents.
The similarly reformatted Kickin' Butts program did not improve quit rates.

abstract OBJECTIVE: The goal was to compare the efficacy of school-based, multisession, group smoking-cessation interventions versus a single group session in increasing quit rates among adolescent smokers.
METHODS: Eight schools were assigned randomly to use 1 of 2 group smoking-cessation programs previously shown to increase quit rates among adolescents (Not on Tobacco [NOT] or Kickin' Butts).
We refor-matted the programs to twice-weekly 25 - to 30 - minute sessions delivered during lunch periods.
Smoking status was assessed at end of program (EOP) and 1, 3, 6, and 12 months later.
Self-reported quit status was confirmed with salivary cotinine levels.
RESULTS: A total of 407 students (56% black and 52% female; mean age: 16 years) participated.
Kickin' Butts participants were no more likely to quit than control subjects.

In the conservative analysis (stu-dents with missing follow-up data classified as smokers), NOT participants were 1.92 times (95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.09 - 3.40 times) more likely to self-report quitting at 1 month.

In the Bayesian analysis (missing follow-up data imputed by using all available data), NOT participants were significantly more likely than control subjects to self-report quitting at EOP (relative risk [RR]: 1.26 [95% CI: 1.10 - 1.43]), 1 month (RR: 2.07 [95% CI: 1.68 - 2.56]), and 12 months (RR: 1.58 [95% CI: 1.22 - 2.04]).
Cotinine-confirmed quit rates were significantly greater among NOT participants, compared with control subjects, at EOP and 1 month.
CONCLUSIONS: The reformatted NOT program had a modest effect on adolescents interested in quitting.
Kickin' Butts, as reformatted for this project, did not have any effect on quit rates.
Pediatrics 2009;124: e187 - e194
Students were recruited at 8 public high schools, including 4 in Baltimore and 4 in Howard County, Maryland.

In the Baltimore schools, the project was advertised through flyers posted in hallways and the school health centers, through word of mouth, through public address system announcements, and by health center staff members.
In the Howard County schools, the project was advertised through public announcements and word of mouth.
By including urban and suburban schools, the study achieved a racially diverse sample.
Interested students were screened for eligibility (self-described smoker with interest in quitting).
Students referred for disciplinary reasons were ineligible.
Parental consent and student assent were obtained from eligible students.
Parents and students were told that the program involved a behavioral intervention and that no drugs would be used.
Before randomization, participants completed the baseline questionnaire and provided saliva for measurement of salivary cotinine levels.

During the first year of the project, 2 schools in Baltimore and 2 in Howard County were selected randomly to administer the NOT program, whereas the other 4 used Kickin' Butts; during the second year, schools that used Kickin' Butts previously administered the NOT program and vice versa.

To maximize the probability that there would be comparable numbers of control and intervention students at each school, students were assigned randomly at each school in blocks of 4 (within each block, 2 students were assigned randomly to the intervention group and 2 to the control group).
An American Lung Association-certified NOT trainer reformulated the 10 NOT program sessions of 50 minutes each into 20 lunch sessions of 25 to 30 minutes each.
The developer of Kickin' Butts (Dr W. P. Adelman) 7 converted the 8 program sessions of 50 minutes each into 15 lunch sessions of 25 to 30 minutes each.
Original NOT or Kickin' Butts program materials were used during the sessions.

During the singlesession (control) intervention, which was implemented at the same time as NOT and Kickin' Butts, students were encouraged to quit and were provided with a variety of youth-oriented smoking-cessation pamphlets.
Lunch was provided at each session, and students received modest incentives at each attended session.
Groups consisted of both boys and girls.
Leaders of the NOT and Kickin' Butts sessions were trained by the certified NOT trainer who had reformulated the program and by the developer of Kickin' Butts, respectively.
Leaders were graduate students in psychology, substitute or retired teachers, or staff members from other research projects at the Bloomberg School of Public Health.
Local health science or nursing students, trained by Dr Joffe, conducted the single-session program.

The project was approved by the Bloomberg School of Public Health Committee on Human Research, the institutional review board of the Baltimore City Health Department, the Division of Research, Evaluation, Assessment, and Accountability of the Baltimore City Public School System, Howard County Public School System administrative officers, and all 8 school principals.

Students who completed the consent/ assent process (total N 񮽙 407) were enrolled over 2 years, as follows: autumn 2002, Baltimore, n 񮽙 106; winter 2003, Howard County, n 񮽙 62; autumn 2003, Baltimore, n 񮽙 174; winter 2004, Howard County, n 񮽙 65.

For each intervention program, our planned sample size was 188, the number needed to have 80% power to detect an absolute difference in quit rates of 15% (assuming 20% for the intervention group and 5% for the control group, with 20% attrition).
The analytic sample consists of 387 students with complete baseline data.
Baseline and follow-up surveys contained measures of current and past smoking behaviors, quitting history, nicotine dependence, and stages of change regarding plans to quit.
Follow-up questionnaires were administered to all students at EOP and 1, 6, and 12 months later.
An abbreviated follow-up assessment occurred at 3 months; students were asked whether they had quit smoking and whether they had smoked a cigarette in the past 30 days.
At EOP and 1, 6, and 12 months, students who reported quitting were asked to provide a saliva specimen for measurement of cotinine levels.

Surveys and saliva specimens were obtained in schools if possible; otherwise, they were collected at another location of the student's choosing or, as a last resort, by telephone (with no saliva collected).
Quit status was measured on the basis of self-reports and salivary cotinine levels.
For self-reports, students were classified as quitting if they reported quitting and not smoking in the previous 30 days.
Biochemical verification of quit status (except at 3 months) was confirmed if the salivary cotinine level was 񮽙15 ng/mL.
12 Salivary cotinine collection kits were supplied by J-2 Laboratories (Tucson, AZ).

We used intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis to assess program effects on quit status, using proportions and relative risks (RRs) to quantify the probability of self-reported quitting and true quitting and comparing treated and control adolescents separately according to intervention group.
We used 2 approaches to handle missing data.
The first, more-conservative approach considered students with missing data at a given follow-up point to be still smoking.
Similarly, students who reported quitting but did not provide saliva for cotinine analysis were considered to be cotinine-confirmed smokers.
As an alternative to this approach, we performed a Bayesian analysis in which we imputed missing self-report and cotinine data on the basis of a longitudinal model for their joint distribution.

This analysis assumed that (1) data were missing at random, so that the likelihood of having missing self-report or cotinineconfirmed smoking status data depended only on the observed data, and a self-reported smoker was a cotinine-confirmed smoker.

Our model for the joint distribution at each follow-up time was assumed to depend on known predictors of adolescent smoking cessation, including treatment assignment, school, whether the child sees himself or herself as a regular smoker, whether the child wants to quit for good, stage of change regarding quitting, a measure of nicotine dependence, and self-reported smoking status and confirmed smoking status from previous follow-up visits (where applicable).
Noninformative prior distributions were used in the analysis.

We used the MetropolisHastings algorithm to obtain 1000 realizations of the missing data and then estimated the distribution of the RR of quitting (self-reported and cotinineconfirmed) according to treatment group on the basis of the 1000 full data sets (complete plus imputed missing data).

(2) "Which cigarette would you hate to give up most" (first cigarette in morning, any other cigarette before noon, any other cigarette in afternoon, or any other cigarette in evening)?
(3) "Do you find it difficult not to smoke in places where it is forbidden?"
(4) "Do you smoke if you are so ill that you are in bed most of the day?"

Contemplation of quitting questions; precontemplation stage, no responses to both questions; contemplation stage, plan to quit in next 6 mo but not in next 30 d; determination/preparation stage, plan to quit in next 30 days 11 ): (1) "Do you think you will quit smoking in the next 6 months" (yes/ no)?
(2) "Do you think you will quit smoking in the next 30 days" (yes/no)?
pared with the control group, in the NOT arm of the study (P 񮽙 .02) ().
More than 50% of the subjects were black, and 29% were non-Hispanic white.
The sample was divided evenly between boys and girls.
Approximately one half of the subjects described themselves as regular smokers.
There was substantial variability in the age at first whole cigarette smoked.
Students were divided approximately equally into mild (scores of 4 -7), moderate (scores of 8 -11), and high (scores of 12 - 16) categories of nicotine dependence (average score: 9.76).
Most students (84%) reported wanting to quit for good, but only one third wanted to quit within 30 days.

In the intervention groups, 17% of students attended 񮽙75% of the sessions, 27% attended 50% to 75% of the sessions, 39% attended 񮽙1 session but fewer than one half of the sessions, and 17% did not attend any sessions.

Compared with students who were in the control group or who attended 񮽙50% of the sessions, students who attended 񮽙50% of the group sessions were significantly more likely to be regular smokers and to have higher nicotine dependence scores but were significantly less likely to plan to quit for good or to report that they were planning to quit in the next 30 days.
Response rates were 80% at EOP, 66% at 1 month, 73% at 3 months, 69% at 6 months, and 62% at 12 months.
Among those eligible to provide a saliva specimen, collection rates were 84% at EOP, 75% at 1 month, 61% at 6 months, and 56% at 12 months.
We found no statistically significant differences in the proportions of missing data for intervention versus control groups at any point.   data.

For Kickin' Butts, there were no significant differences between quit rates for the intervention versus control groups at any follow-up time, whether measured on the basis of selfreport or cotinine data.
Self-reported quit rates were higher among NOT program recipients than among control subjects at 1 month (RR: 1.92 [95% confidence interval: 1.09 -3.40]).
There were no statistically significant differences for the NOT program at any follow-up point, according to cotinine analysis.
In addition, reclassifying students who reported quitting but had missing salivary cotinine data as having quit did not change the analysis (data not shown).

Using a lower salivary cotinine level (eg, 8 ng/mL) to define quit status did not change the analysis, because there were only 2 students with cotinine levels of 񮽙15 ng/mL (both with levels of 11 ng/mL).
presents the results of the Bayesian approach.
We observed higher self-report and cotinine-confirmed quit rates, compared with the results in which all participants with missing data were considered smokers.

On average, our imputation algorithm suggested that 7% to 35% of adolescents with missing smoking data were quitters    The results represent results of the ITT analysis applied to the imputed self-reported and confirmed (through salivary cotinine measurement) quitting status by using a full Bayesian imputation model.

In contrast, students in the Kickin' Butts program had significantly lower (relative to control subjects) self-reported quit rates at 3 months (RR: 0.71 [95% CI: 0.56 -0.90]) and 6 months (RR: 0.80 [95% CI: 0.66 -0.95]).
Bayesian analysis of cotinine-confirmed quit status revealed evidence of the effectiveness of the NOT program.
NOT program participants were more likely than control subjects to quit at EOP (RR: 1.20 [95% CI: 1.02 - 1.40]) and at 1 month (RR: 1.57 [95% CI: 1.7 - 2.21]) but not at 6 or 12 months.
There were no significant differences in cotinineconfirmed quit rates between control subjects and students attending the Kickin' Butts program at anytime.

By using a rigorous, randomized, controlled design and sophisticated statistical analyses for handling missing data, we did not identify any positive effects of the reformatted Kickin' Butts program on quit rates.
In contrast, we did find program effects for the NOT program.
In the conservative analysis, the NOT program yielded higher rates of self-reported quitting at 1 month.
The Bayesian analysis yielded more favorable RR estimates for the NOT program, with the exception of selfreported outcomes at 3 months.
This analysis identified significant positive effects at EOP, 1 month, and 12 months for self-reported quitting and at EOP and 1 month for cotinine-confirmed quitting.
Bayesian analysis uses all available observed data to impute missing outcomes.

For example, if an individual reported quitting at EOP and 3 months but did not provide information at 1 month, then the Bayesian approach would use the observed outcomes and covariates for that individual and others to infer the missing 1 - month outcome stochastically.
In contrast, the conservative analysis would deem the individual a smoker.
compares the average imputed quit rates among those with missing outcomes and those with observed outcomes at each follow-up point.
In 30 of 36 comparisons, imputed quit rates were lower than observed rates.
Therefore, the Bayesian analysis, at most follow-up assessments, imputed higher smoking rates for subjects who did not appear for their assessments than for those who did.
It is impossible to determine from the observed data which analysis is correct.
It is, however, scientifically plausible that the true results lie somewhere between the Bayesian and conservative results.
Therefore, we can infer that the Kickin' Butts program (as implemented) was ineffective, whereas the modified NOT program seemed modestly effective in increasing quit rates.

To address the potential concern regarding baseline imbalance in contemplation of quitting within 6 months in the NOT arm of the study, we replicated all analyses within strata of contemplation status.
There was no evidence that the results for the NOT program were driven by this imbalance.

Similarly, because students who had smoked 񮽙50 cigarettes in their lifetimes could be considered experimental smokers and more likely to quit, we repeated the analyses among this subgroup; the results were essentially the same.

Ina review of NOT program data over a 6 - year period, Horn et al 9 noted EOP quit rates that were almost twice as high for the intervention group (14.9%), compared with the control group (7.9%), in conservative ITT analyses.

It is difficult to compare our results directly with those of Horn et al, because those authors used an exhaled carbon monoxide-confirmed 24 - hour abstinence period as the definition of quitting, whereas we used a 30 - day abstinence period.

The recent analysis by Kohler et al 18 of the NOT program in Alabama, which was an effectiveness study as opposed to an efficacy study, demonstrated a positive effect of the NOT program on EOP 30 - day quit rates (6.3% in NOT schools vs 2.4% in control schools).

Our self-reported and cotinineconfirmed quit rates were higher among both NOT participants and control subjects, but the differences between groups at EOP were generally comparable to those of Kohler et al 18 (4% - 7%).

It is encouraging that the NOT program seemed to be effective among our racially diverse sample of adolescents, which included a significant proportion (27%) of adolescents who had smoked 񮽙50 cigarettes in their lifetimes.
Whereas previous research suggested that light-smoking adolescents do not become addicted, morerecent research suggested addiction even at low levels of smoking.
Therefore, smoking-cessation programs should be offered to lightsmoking adolescents who express the desire to quit.
Our study was not powered to analyze results according to race; future studies could examine racial differences in program effectiveness with appropriate study designs.

Our self-reported quit rates in the intervention and control groups were higher than those reported in previous NOT studies, but the ranges reported in those studies were broad (12% - 30% for NOT participants and 3% - 18% for control subjects).
The rates we reported are similar to those in a previous smoking-cessation study performed in Baltimore 7 and in a recent study conducted in pediatric primary care clinics.
Our study has several limitations.
Research assistants collecting the data were not blinded to the students' group assignment.

Support for the project varied among schools; program effectiveness might have been affected by the school's support and the students' perception of that support, as well as by the school's and students' experience with the previous year's program.
We attempted to minimize the impact of such factors by conducting each program once in each school, with the order chosen randomly.
Furthermore, because we found a positive effect only for the NOT program, we do not think that these limitations affected the reported outcomes.
We assigned students randomly within schools, rather than according to school, to minimize potential effects of the school environment on program success.
This approach might have worked against the success of the intervention.
It was noted anecdotally that some students assigned randomly to the NOT or Kickin' Butts programs lost interest when their friends were assigned to the control group.
This may explain why 17% of students did not attend a single session of the intervention; those students also might have been less receptive to program content when they did attend.

It also is possible that students in the single-session group learned additional quit strategies beyond those outlined in the pamphlets they received; this would have biased our study against finding a difference.
We were able to contact 񮽙60% of subjects at each follow-up point.
We think that conducting the research in schools, as well collecting students' home and cellular telephone numbers and contact information for friends, facilitated follow-up monitoring.
In the Bayesian self-report analysis, the effectiveness of the NOT program decreased overtime but reemerged at 12 months.
Because we did not include booster sessions in our reformatted programs (the NOT program does include such sessions), the effect at 12 months cannot be attributable to the impact of those sessions.
It maybe that students initially were successful at quitting but then relapsed by 6 months.
The increased quit rates at 12 months may reflect the fact that students again decided to quit and drew on skills learned previously in the NOT program.
Because positive effects for the NOT program were inconsistently present at 12 months, investigators choosing to adopt the reformatted program should consider including booster sessions.
We did not test the NOT Program or Kickin' Butts programs under the original program conditions.
Rather, we carefully adapted the programs to a lunchtime format so that they could be delivered in schools when classroom time or afterschool time was not available.
In doing so, we necessarily altered the individual session content, although not the overall amount of material that ultimately was delivered.
Adapting the programs to shorter sessions delivered twice-weekly and use of mixed-gender groups did not seem to affect the impact of the NOT program.

Although there maybe other reasons why Kickin' Butts did not succeed, it must be considered that reformatting Kickin' Butts to shorter sessions delivered twice-weekly did affect its effectiveness adversely.
The NOT program, even in a modified format, modestly increased quit rates among program participants.
We cannot recommend the reformatted Kickin' Butts program as a smokingcessation program.
